description: From Middle English teren, from Old English teran (‚Äúto tear, lacerate‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *teranƒÖ (‚Äúto tear, tear apart, rip‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *der- (‚Äúto tear, tear apart‚Äù).

Cognate with Scots tere, teir, tair (‚Äúto rend, lacerate, wound, rip, tear out‚Äù), Dutch teren (‚Äúto eliminate, efface, live, survive by consumption‚Äù), German zehren (‚Äúto consume, misuse‚Äù), German zerren (‚Äúto tug, rip, tear‚Äù), Danish t√¶re (‚Äúto consume‚Äù), Swedish t√§ra (‚Äúto fret, consume, deplete, use up‚Äù), Icelandic t√¶ra (‚Äúto clear, corrode‚Äù). Outside Germanic, cognate to Ancient Greek Œ¥Œ≠œÅœâ (d√©r≈ç, ‚Äúto skin‚Äù), Albanian ther (‚Äúto slay, skin, pierce‚Äù). Doublet of tire.

entries.meaning: A hole or break caused by tearing.
examples: A small tear is easy to mend, if it is on the seam.

verbs.description: tear (third-person singular simple present tears, present participle tearing, simple past tore, past participle torn or (now colloquial and nonstandard) tore)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To rend (a solid material) by holding or restraining in two places and pulling apart, whether intentionally or not; to destroy or separate.
examples: He suffered, poor man, at seeing her so badly dressed, with laceless boots, and the arm-holes of her pinafore torn down to the hips; for the charwoman took no care of her.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To injure as if by pulling apart.
examples: He tore some muscles in a weight-lifting accident.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To destroy or reduce abstract unity or coherence, such as social, political or emotional.
examples: He was torn by conflicting emotions.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (an opening) with force or energy.
examples: A piece of debris tore a tiny straight channel through the satellite.
His boss will tear him a new one when he finds out.
The artillery tore a gap in the line.

entries.meaning: (transitive, often with off or out) To remove by tearing.
examples: Tear the coupon out of the newspaper.

entries.meaning: (transitive, of structures, with down) To demolish
examples: The slums were torn down to make way for the new development.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To move or act with great speed, energy, or violence.
examples: He went tearing down the hill at 90 miles per hour.
The tornado lingered, tearing through town, leaving nothing upright.
He tore into the backlog of complaints.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To smash or enter something with great force.
examples: The chain shot tore into the approaching line of infantry.

description: From Middle English teer (‚Äútear‚Äù), from Old English tƒìar, from Proto-West Germanic *tahr, from Proto-Germanic *tahrƒÖ (‚Äútear‚Äù), from Proto-Indo-European *d√°·∏±ru- (‚Äútears‚Äù).
Cognates include Old Norse t√°r (Danish t√•re and Norwegian t√•re), Old High German zahar (German Z√§hre), Gothic êçÑêå∞êå≤êçÇ (tagr), Irish deoir and Latin lacrima.

entries.meaning: A drop of clear, salty liquid produced from the eyes by crying or irritation.
examples: There were big tears rolling down Lisa's cheeks.
Ryan wiped the tear from the paper he was crying on.

entries.meaning: Something in the form of a transparent drop of fluid matter; also, a solid, transparent, tear-shaped drop, as of some balsams or resins.
(glass manufacture) A partially vitrified bit of clay in glass.
That which causes or accompanies tears; a lament; a dirge.

verbs.description: tear (third-person singular simple present tears, present participle tearing, simple past and past participle teared)

examples: Her eyes began to tear in the harsh wind.
